subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] keyboard/lexical set proposal
msgSnippet: I agree totally with Ted.  The logic of easier writing translates into easier reading.  I am therefore in favour of including both alternates in the mapping.
messageBody:
I agree totally with Ted.  The logic of easier writing translates into easier reading.  I am therefore in favour of including both alternates in the mapping.  When typing in Jerome (which I do quite a lot) I will always use the alternate that matches the preceding or following letter to give a logical and aesthetic "join".

Moira

On 18/12/2007, Ted Larson Freeman <freeman@...> wrote:

In my view, the alternate letters for #23 and #36 make reading easier.
When I first read the QM, the half-letters and advanced letter
connections seemed difficult, but the alternate letters were as easy
to learn as any other letters in the QS alphabet. They are, after all,
just letters, and it didn't occur to me that I should postpone
learning them just because they are introduced in the Senior section
of the manual. As I've pointed out before, the rules for their usage
are so straightforward that it would be a snap to incorporate these
letters directly into a QS dictionary.

How do you write a word such as 'hen'? (I'll use QS-SAMPA in curly
braces again.) I find {hEq} the natural way to write it, not {hEn}. In
fact, {hEn} looks quite strange, and slows the reader down. Why would
someone lift the pen like that? In the same way, words such as 'us'
and 'lull' look much better written {Vs} and {lVl} as opposed to {ys}
and {lyl}. These preferences apply whether or not the letters are
actually connected.

Personally, I would redraw the boundary between Junior QS and Senior
QS, placing these two letters on the Junior side. This is the reason
I've included them in discussions of the QS keyboard mapping.

When reading the output of your news transliteration program, the lack
of these alternate letters slows me down. (I'm not the first one to
mention this.) An example from today's news is 'spending'. I think it
looks better as {spEqdN} rather than {spEndN}. Rather than typing, try
writing the two versions out by hand. I think you'll see what I mean.

My hunch is that for most people on this list, QS is first and
foremost a script for writing by hand. I suspect this is the reason
the keyboard mapping we use for fonts and document exchange isn't an
important issue for the majority. I think we'll be lucky if we get 15
votes. (By the way, I've worked out two new mapping proposals, which I
will add to the list and post in the next day or two.)

Ted

> > They are not half-letters. They are alternate letters. Please review
> > the Quickscript Manual.
> >
>
> Yes, but they belong to the group of letters that are meant to make hand
> writing easier, not to make reading easier. Reading theory posits that
> we read by recognizing the shapes of words, so having extra shapes slows
> reading down. These alternate letters are not part of junior QS
> according to the manual, and in my opinion they have no place in a
> junior QS font, which is what I believe we are discussing.
>
> However, in the spirit of moving things along, I see that my proposal
> has a few free spots, so I'll just assign the half letters to them.
>
> How will we determine what an accurate vote is? There are 300 users on
> this email list, but only a small number of them seem to participate. I
> would like to have at least 50 users vote (thought that may be
> unrealistic), had require that each vote be accompanied by a one or two
> line explanation for the choice, to ensure a we get good input before
> making a final decision.
>
> Paul
